JUDGES: Christos Rozakis;Dean Spielmann;George Nicolaou;Giorgio Malinverni;Khanlar Hajiyev;Sverre Erik Jebens
TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in Split . She was represented before the ORG by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

On DATE , at TIME , the applicant went to dispose of rubbish in bins placed in an open parking area in front of the apartment building where she lived in PERSON when suddenly her neighbour , a certain PERSON , approached her , slapped her in the face and allegedly began to strangle her while threatening to kill her .

The applicant managed to escape and ran home . Once inside her flat , she telephoned the police and reported the incident . TIME QUANTITY police officers arrived at the applicant ’s flat and interviewed her . It appears that they also interviewed GPE The police officers instructed the applicant to see a doctor , which she did DATE .

The police lodged a complaint against ORG with ORG ( ORG ) and proceedings were instituted against ORG before that court . The applicant was not informed of these proceedings , nor called as a witness . On DATE the said court issued a minor offences order against ORG , under section CARDINAL of LAW . It found that GPE had committed a breach of the peace by attacking the applicant verbally and physically on DATE , an offence under LAW , and sentenced him to pay a fine in the amount of CARDINAL NORP kunas ( HRK ) and the costs of the proceedings in the amount of HRK CARDINAL . The relevant part of this order reads :
“ Defendant PERSON ...
is guilty

because on DATE at TIME in PERSON , ... in the parking area in front of a building , he committed a breach of the peace by verbally and then physically attacking PERSON and pushing her and hitting her in the face and neck , after which he went away ,
He committed a breach of the peace by shouting , uttering insults and fighting
and thus committed a minor offence under LAW of ORG ... “
The applicant was not informed of this decision .

On DATE the applicant lodged a criminal complaint against GPE with the ORG ( Općinsko državno odvjetništvo u ORG ) alleging that on DATE PERSON had approached her in a car park in front of the apartment building where she lived , had slapped her and begun to strangle her while threatening to kill her . The applicant enclosed the police report and medical documentation of DATE showing that she had visible finger marks on her throat and pain in that area , especially if touched or when swallowing .

In a letter of CARDINAL DATE the ORG Attorney ’s ORG informed the applicant that it had decided not to open an official investigation . It informed her that she nevertheless had the right to seek a decision in writing declaring her criminal complaint inadmissible . The applicant sought a decision in writing . Her request was complied with and the applicant ’s criminal complaint was declared inadmissible on the grounds that she had failed to comply with the DATE time limit under LAW since she had lodged her criminal complaint on DATE although she had learnt about the incident in question DATE , namely , on DATE .

The applicant then lodged a request for an investigation with a ORG investigating judge . She qualified the acts of violence at issue as criminal offences under LAW ( inflicting bodily injury ) , CARDINAL ( making threats ) , CARDINAL ) ( verbal insult ) , CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ( vigilantism ) and CARDINAL ( violent behaviour ) of LAW . On DATE a CARDINAL - judge panel of ORG dismissed the request . The relevant part of that decision reads as follows :

“ After the Split State Attorney ’s ORG had declared the applicant ’s criminal complaint against ORG inadmissible in respect of the criminal offence under LAW , the injured party , PERSON , acting as subsidiary prosecutor , took the place of the prosecutor by lodging a request for an investigation ...

The investigating judge did not consent to the [ applicant ’s ] request . As regards the criminal offence of violent behaviour , he stated that ORG actions did not constitute the elements of that criminal offence . The prosecution in respect of all the other charges had become time - barred since the injured party had filed her criminal complaint outside the statutory time - limit .
The request of the injured party , acting as subsidiary prosecutor , is unfounded .

The investigating judge is right in his statement that ORG ’s actions did not satisfy the elements of the criminal offence of violent behaviour . The information in the case file shows that ORG attacked the applicant because he was irritated with her attitude towards his child . Since the crucial element of the offence of violent behaviour is an unmotivated attack , and [ the attack of GPE against the applicant ] was obviously motivated , there was no ground for granting the injured party ’s request in respect of the criminal offence of violent behaviour .

The other charges against ORG , which are to be the subject of a private prosecution , have become time - barred in view of the fact that the offence was committed on DATE and the injured party lodged her criminal complaint on DATE , that is to say , after the expiry of the DATE time - limit from DATE on which she learnt of the offence and of the identity of the perpetrator .

The time - limit for making an application for prosecution under LAW is DATE from the date on which the applicant learnt of the criminal offence and the identity of the perpetrator . The injured party failed to comply with that time - limit , however . Therefore , her request for an investigation against ORG for the criminal offences under ORG , CARDINAL ) , ORG ) and CARDINAL ) of LAW is unfounded .
An appeal by the applicant on DATE was declared inadmissible by ORG investigating judge on DATE as not provided for under domestic law .
An appeal by the applicant against the latter decision was dismissed by a CARDINAL - judge panel of ORG on DATE .

On DATE the applicant lodged a further appeal , which was declared inadmissible in a decision of the ORG investigating judge as not provided for under domestic law . An appeal by the applicant against that decision was dismissed by a CARDINAL - judge panel of ORG on DATE .

The applicant then lodged a constitutional complaint against the decision of ORG of DATE . On DATE ORG ( Ustavni sud PERSON ) declared it inadmissible , relying on section CARDINAL of LAW , on the ground that it did not concern the merits of the case but was lodged against a procedural decision of ORG of DATE and concerned the applicant ’s appeals which were inadmissible under domestic law .
The relevant part of section CARDINAL of LAW ( Official Gazette no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , of CARDINAL DATE , PERSON o PERSON ) reads as follows :

“ CARDINAL . Anyone may lodge a constitutional complaint with ORG if he or she deems that the individual act of a state body , a body of local and regional self - government , or a legal person with public authority , which has determined his or her rights and obligations , or a suspicion or accusation of a criminal act , has violated his or her human rights or fundamental freedoms or his or her right to local and regional self - government guaranteed by LAW ( hereinafter : constitutional right ) ...
The relevant parts of LAW ( PERSON , ORG no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) read as follows :
“ ( CARDINAL ) Criminal proceedings in respect of criminal offences shall be instituted by ORG in the interest of GPE and its citizens .

( CARDINAL ) The law may exceptionally make provision for criminal proceedings in respect of certain criminal offences to be instituted upon a private prosecution or for ORG to institute criminal proceedings upon [ a private ] application . ”
“ Whosoever inflicts bodily injury on another person or impairs another person ’s health shall be fined or sentenced to imprisonment for a term not exceeding DATE . ”
“ Criminal proceedings for the offence of inflicting bodily injury ( LAW ) shall be instituted by means of a private prosecution . ”

“ ( CARDINAL ) Whosoever threatens another person with harm in order to intimidate or frighten that person shall be fined CARDINAL DATE wages or sentenced to imprisonment for a term not exceeding DATE .
( CARDINAL ) Whosoever seriously threatens to kill another person ... shall be fined or sentenced to imprisonment for a term not exceeding one year .
( CARDINAL ) Criminal proceedings for the criminal offences defined in DATE and QUANTITY of this Article shall be instituted upon [ a private ] application . ”

“ Whosoever places another person in a degrading position for such purposes as violent abuse , ill - treatment or particularly insolent behaviour in public shall be sentenced to imprisonment for a term of DATE . ”
The relevant provisions of LAW ( Zakon o kaznenom postupku , ORG nos . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , DATE , CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) provide as follows :
“ ( CARDINAL ) Criminal proceedings shall be instituted and conducted at the request of a qualified prosecutor only . ...

( CARDINAL ) In respect of criminal offences subject to public prosecution the qualified prosecutor shall be the ORG Attorney and in respect of the criminal offences to be prosecuted privately the qualified prosecutor shall be a private prosecutor .

( CARDINAL ) Unless otherwise provided by law , the ORG Attorney shall bring a criminal prosecution where there is a reasonable suspicion that an identified person has committed a criminal offence subject to public prosecution and where there are no legal impediments to the prosecution of that person .

( CARDINAL ) Where the ORG Attorney finds that there are no grounds on which to institute or conduct criminal proceedings , the injured party , acting as subsidiary prosecutor , may take his place under the conditions prescribed by this LAW . ”

Articles CARDINAL to CARDINAL regulate the rights and duties of a private prosecutor and of an injured party acting as a subsidiary prosecutor . The Criminal Code distinguishes between these CARDINAL roles . A private prosecutor ( privatni tužitelj ) is the injured party who brings a private prosecution in respect of criminal offences for which such prosecution is expressly prescribed by LAW ( these are offences of a lesser degree ) . The injured party , as acting subsidiary prosecutor ( oštećeni kao tužitelj ) , takes over criminal proceedings in respect of criminal offences normally prosecuted by the ORG where the relevant prosecuting authorities have decided DATE for whatever reason – not to prosecute .

“ ( CARDINAL ) ... an application for prosecution or a request to prosecute shall be brought within DATE from the date on which [ the person concerned ] learnt of the criminal offence and the identity of the perpetrator .
“ ( CARDINAL ) A request to prosecute shall be lodged with the competent ORG Attorney ’s ORG and a private prosecution with the competent court .
( CARDINAL ) Where the injured party has lodged a criminal complaint ... it shall be considered that he or she has also thereby lodged a request to prosecute .

( CARDINAL ) Where the injured party has lodged a criminal complaint or a request to prosecute but the [ competent authorities ] establish that the criminal offence in question should be prosecuted by means of a private prosecution , the criminal complaint or the request to prosecute shall be treated as a timely private prosecution if it has been submitted within the time - limit prescribed for [ bringing ] a private prosecution ... ”

Pursuant to LAW , the ORG Attorney is under a duty to inform the injured party within DATE of a decision not to prosecute and of that party ’s right to take over the proceedings , and to inform that party of the steps to be taken .
“ ( CARDINAL ) ORG shall report criminal offences subject to public prosecution .
“ ( CARDINAL ) A [ criminal ] complaint shall be lodged with the competent ORG Attorney ’s [ ORG ] in writing or orally .

“ Where the allegations set out in the criminal complaint do not concern a criminal offence subject to public prosecution , the competent ORG Attorney shall declare it inadmissible in a reasoned decision ... ”

Article CARDINAL , paragraph CARDINAL , allows a private prosecutor and the injured party , acting as subsidiary prosecutor , to lodge a request for prosecution and other submissions with an investigating judge of a competent court .

“ ( CARDINAL ) Subject to any contrary provision in this LAW , parties to the proceedings and any other person whose rights have been infringed may lodge an appeal against decisions of an investigating judge and other decisions adopted by the first - instance court .
( CARDINAL ) Subject to any contrary provision in this LAW , an appeal is not allowed against a decision of a panel adopted before or during the investigation .
( CARDINAL ) An appeal is never allowed against decisions of ORG . ”
